title: Does learning music theory take the joy out of music? - Quora

response.answer_text: The word ‘theory’ itself perhaps has negative connotations - and if your process of learning music theory involves being formally examined on it, then for some people this may potentially take the joy out of their experiences with music theory. Aside from the process of how you go about learning theory, I think it depends upon the choices (both conscious and unconscious) you make in applying the music theory knowledge you’ve acquired in your practices/arrangements/compositions, as well as when you listen to music. I think a relevant factor here is considering the multifaceted ways in which people find joy in music. Some people particularly connect to a song’s lyrics, its harmonies, rhythm etc., or a combination of some/all of the above. For me, perhaps because my musical experiences mainly involved playing musical instruments & orchestras, I’ve become somewhat predisposed to resonating more with the instrumentation of the music I hear and play. Music theory furthered my ability to decipher the instrumentation of a song/piece, and overall deepened my passion and connection with the music I listen to and play. Just as music theory may contribute towards how you enjoy music, it may possibly work the other way in some respect. I’ve heard of some people who are well-versed in music theory, but had the tendency of falling into the trap of being preoccupied with following particular rules & forms of music theory (to the extent that they feel they wish could ‘shut off their brain’ from being analytical with the music they make/listen to).

Nothing can take one’s joy - one has to surrender it. I sometimes wish I had formal training, believing (with the benefit/hindrance of 20/20 hindsight) that I would’ve accepted the discipline and retained my creativity and independence. But then I am told by trained players that they couldn’t dream of doing what I do, and still others who said that if I were “properly trained, the music would be better served” - agreeing with both statements - and figure that I’m right where I oughta be. Music theory is a way to understand the how and why of music. Not the only way, mind you, but a way. Not unlike Pimsleur and Berlitz and Rosetta Stone - 3 ways to learn an language, but certainly not the only 3, and not nearly as effective, as enriching nor as enjoyable as listening to, speaking with, and learning from native speakers. Some people abhor book learning. Some bristle when being told what to do; others can’t tolerate being corrected. For such people, it might seem that a music theory course is sucking all of the joy out of their relationship with music. But as with any relationship, do not allow anyone to define how or why you feel what you feel about anyone - including music. I will say this, though: music has its own language and glossary, just like ballet, judo, poker, race driving, hiphop and tennis. It can be tough going for someone who doesn’t understand basic vocabulary - verbally and musically.

That question does not have a straight answer because it depends a lot on the context you’re in. We can’t by any means, conceive an orchestra director, that doesn’t dominates music theory “in his sleep”. On the other hand, if certain music genres are translated into musical notation, we end by finding out that it will carry more text instructions than music notation. When I go to the internet, searching for music sheet to work out one or another solo or piece of traditional music (Irish, for instance), I find lots of ways to write the same piece. Why? Because people is trying to write the expression in music notation and it is usually difficult as it is a type of music that uses a lot of twists and turns for which there are no proper music signs. Sometimes, the very use of the compass bar, should be dismissed because it brings confusion into music that is not compass oriented. So, musical notation has its’ very important place, but sometimes requires so much concentration that is counterproductive. Nevertheless, knowing music theory and dominate it, will help you a LOT. And will bring you much additional joy (even when you chose not to use it). On the other hand, knowing musical theory in the context of composition is absolutely essential and will make of you a much better composer. The knowledge of how scales work and sound, how general aesthetics command the composition process, how you can take advantage of certain technics, and much more, will make a huge difference and will bring you joy and success. I don’t mean you have to use what you learn. I mean you can choose. You will be free to choose the best option instead of being limited by ignorance.

It depends on the situation. First of all, nothing good comes with very little effort. Starting to learn some instrument means learning the basics like theory, because those are the skills you will be using subconsciously when you’ll be learning to play something complex. It would be fair to say that I hated my first 2–3 years of the musical school exactly because of the boring math-like chord-building crap, but when it came to playing real pieces of music, Bach, Beethoven, Mozart, especially with Bach, came the understanding of the importance of all those scales trainings, fast arpeggios exercises, because Bach is considered to be the inventor of polyphony. If we take the collection of his Inventions, it becomes different, you’ll need your skills applied to the both hands because you’ll be playing two different melodies with each hand. That’s why they made us play scales with both hands. So musical theory is just a tool, another feature that will help you grow as s musician, no matter what instrument you play. I forgot all the theory even before my music academic training was over, because I used my ears instead, that worked great. Until many years later, I took a guitar and learned to play it, there was a moment, whenI realized that I cannot become a better guitarist if I don’t recall all the theory, at some point every musician stumbles across this ‘problem’, it is like arithmetics or simple divisions and multiplications in math will become more and more complex, but you can always use a calculator, if you figure out how to make a correct input of what you need to count.

Why should it? Perhaps if you have a lousy teacher, who squeezes the joy out of music theory, or who places the theory at a higher plane than the music, you could have that effect. But when you learn music, your brain is continually taking in emotional and logical information - and intertwines the emotion and the logic. Human beings are made to wonder why things happen and how they work! When I was a child, I batted on a primarily emotional plane. I swung the bat as hard as I could, and would not let anyone give me advice. I eventually figured out my own theory, and developed a way to swing smoothly and make a lot of “singles.” But not until my last few years, playing softball when I was 60 years old, did I discover the theory of making a powerful follow-through. For the first time in my entire life, I hit a ball over an outfielder’s head and got a triple! Was theory exciting or not? But you ccan flunk theory, and still be a great musician; the theory is in you, but just takes an amorphous existence.

Hey Michael; I'd say it partly depends on your musical personality; and also on what theory you study, and where you get your theory information from. Some musicians do without theory study, and even having a teacher; but most of the ones I've run into on Quora have said they were very glad when they finally got around to it. The theory that I learned REALLY helped and speeded up my ear training and expanded my improvisation ideas. And this was pretty traditional tonal Harmony I learned. I've learned to stay away from more recent modal and less tonality centered approaches that are intellectually more confusing. Music theory for me, has always added to my joy, and music appreciation.

There’s a saying: “I know just enough theory not to damage my playing” which always made me laugh as there is a grain of truth there. Here's an analogy that may be helpful: People built homes out of different materials without drawing plans for a long time, they just did it. Then someone figured out how to draw and design before building, and architectural mathematics entered the picture. You don't need a smidgeon of theory to have fun banging on a drum or strumming a guitar, but if you want to compose a symphony, music notation will help you inform the players and share the parts with efficiency. The hardest part is sight-reading two-handed piano music notation. Each hand has its own clef (French for ‘key’) and they have different rules. My first instrument was voice. Learning to follow a melody was quite easy as there was only one clef to ‘decode’. The problem came later, as I mentioned, with piano. There are some musos who are theory geeks and have all kinds of fun with it. Others want to play so bad they skip it. Theory is the map, music is the territory. Be aware of that and you will enjoy both without confusion.

Not if the music comes from within you, from your inner voice. For me, music theory was the key to unlocking massive creative potential. It’s like how learning to type fast allowed me to get my thoughts rapidly and fluidly onto paper. Music theory allows me to play/write rapidly and accurately, gives me great direction expanding harmonically or in whatever direction. It teaches me what’s standard and what’s not. It’s a tool. I never let it control what I do. Learn the “rules,” and break them with a purpose. Or probably more often, follow them in your own unique way. A useful analogy. When I was learning about poetry in English in high school, I got turned off to it and felt creatively stifled because I succumbed to elitist pressure that using normal rhymes or whatever was somehow beneath “real poets.” Don’t let that kind of thinking stop you from creating enjoyable music. It doesn’t have to be some crazy avant-garde super original thing to be great.

Yes, especially if you are forced to learn through theory, like most teachers teach. We must remember that music is an art. And the most important (and funny) aspect of art is: creation… By all means, make your own music from the very start. So imagining music is more important than theory. Find out melody notes by trial and error on your instrument of choice. I prefer the classical guitar because I can sing at the same time and it does not cover my voice, but mostly because most of the music I imagine is classical/folk/pop. The only bit of theory I know is how maj/min/7th chords are formed. If you do not know, you may end up using more unstable/dreary chords, which may even be ok for some pieces. But more than theory, a lot of tries and experimentation are needed to make a good arrangement. You’ve got to play and play and play the same songs many times, adding more and more variations. Theory can help to select what sounds best amongst many choices, but the last judges are your ears and your feeling.

I think the answer to your question is twofold. Yes, absolutely, a focus on music theory for its own sake can certainly strip all the passion, excitement and joy out of music. Music knowledge is just like learning a new language, and the learning is pointless, and the time wasted, if it is not applied. However, if gaining knowledge is achieved through the process of doing, through performing and/or composing with the notion of focusing on what is needed at the time, then you can see the relevance of the knowledge and gain confidence through the application. This is refered to as “just-in-time” education, rather than “just-in-case”. If you can see context and relevance as you gain knowledge, then each new piece offers you new options. I see it as like opening a new door to find another six to explore. It is the sense of exploration that drives you to push into new territories, perhaps not ever explored before!

I cant say ive ever learned musical theory but I would welcome any insight on music from people who have studied it as a proffesional career and you might be right that it takes the joy out of music but only in the sense that you see it in a mysterious way the theory of music can only help understand it you still might see it as boring and uninteresting but one day down the road it might be the difference in making a leap that otherwise wouldnt have been possible, all the great musicians were first students of music and always continue learning, i dont mean that as in going to school although it could, but more as in trying to learn as much About the things that interest you weather it specific genres of music or instruments, history of music, the importance of timing, improvisation, alternate tuning, notation, chord progressions, learn as much as you can and let it take you where ever it may

No quite the opposite. It allows you to appreciate it that much more. Learning music theory you can hear things you never have heard before. Mostly what the accompaniment is doing. Music Theory gives you a leg up on hearing what chords are being used, etc. Also it allows you to actually make an accompaniment. One of my last violin teachers forced me to identify what chords I’d play over my pieces. Then he’d play backup. It’s much more fun to play a boring etude with someone else playing with you. Finally you’re not going to always have a part written out. With jazz and folk music a lot of the time you’re only going to have the chords. As a violinist you’re going to have to know the notes in those chords and figure some accompaniment out. If you have to solo you have to know what scale or scales go with those chords.

Definitely not. Music theory is to music what grammar is to speaking or writing, or having a road map is to driving. You might be able to get along without it, but why bother? With the map you get where you’re going in a more assured way. Plus, you can even take detours!—and know that you can still get where you’re going on time. And the flowers by the side of the road still smell as sweet whether they are “just pretty flowers” or “augmented sixth chords”. There might be a very short adjustment period where one will be thinking more in theoretical terms, and will feel like their pre-existing natural joy in music has been taken away forever. Don’t worry. That phase doesn’t last, and then you will have a tool that will make your music-making (and listening) stronger and more assured than ever before. To me, that’s when the joy really starts to kick in.

My short answer is that for some personality types, me included, joy perhaps could [edit: be identified as being ] a reaction to learning about the abstract music big picture. I’m just not sure about that [edit: feeling], which might give a hint of how I approach playing music. The best musicians create music from a different part of the brain, IMO. Question - Does learning music theory take the joy out of music?

Oh good heavens! No! Theory opens up a world of possibilities. You can appreciate more subtleties. You can see what musicians were getting at where you would otherwise dismiss them for not being real music. You can appreciate structural beauty in longer forms that would otherwise seem to ramble on. You can listen with a more open mind to music from other cultures—provided that your theory is sufficiently generalized. Learning theory is a way to get closer to the thoughts of those who wrote the music you listen to, which allows you connect with them more intimately. Having knowledge of music theory is a little bit like having a translator: you can access more and more since someone has already written down what something means.

Not really, but it should be mainly your ear that guides you. If you’re curious about what your ears hear, then you might want to categorize what you hear so you can either appreciate music in a different way. There’s the aural aspect, music theory is the conceptual aspect. It’s interesting if you’re interested in the conceptual aspect of things, the way things are constructed. One day you could be listening to Der Neugierige by Schubert and when that dude is talking to the brook like “why are you so silent,” like that moment of internal doubt that his fantasy of marrying the Miller Maid is just that, a fantasy. You’ll hear the harmony as a iv chord in a major key, you know, symbolic of his doubts and what not. If you know theory and know that it is modal mixture, provided you’re into these conceptual things, you might be like “that was pretty damn clever Schubert. Oh, also my heart breaks for this young man who is singing about his loved one.”

As long as you keep “Music” and “theory” separate in your head, and during the learning of “theory”, you NEVER EVER EVER lose sight of what “music” is, and continue to learn, explore and create music apart from the “theory”. Theory is just a collection of ideas that are part of a musician’s possible list of tools, to understand some possibilities of music, the external and internal sides of music. Theory can’t and doesn’t determine the content or form of music, unless you’re trapped in the 17th or 18th century and are creating repetitive and lame dances for the Friday evening livingroom of an aristocrat. Or live in Nashville. I DID personally experience a collision that made me choose between theory and music. After learning Grade 4 piano, I was taken off the “grade” piano learning system (which uses carefully chosen songs of different styles to advance your understanding and abilities, including of music theory components) and put into the purely theory-based Royal Conservatory of Canada teaching system, which dropped most “songs” in the teaching, and went into learning “circle of fifths” and theoretical things, but there was no playing of music to be the reward, the outcome of this learning, it was just a constant hike through subject after subject of theory, with NO REGARD whatsoever, on who I was and what I wanted, what music creation or styles of music I could play if I learned this “theory”. It certainly wasn’t asking me what I wanted to learn or why! So, after about 2 years of this, I just lost all patience and walked out on my teacher one day after DEMANDING to apply this stuff to play music, and it wasn’t going to happen. The teacher got pissed and said he could teach me in two weeks how to play all the rock and roll in the world, but the course was the course and that’s all he had to teach. I wasn’t quitting on him, I was quitting on the inhumanity of this experience, this stupid process, and I walked out. I’ve written a nice lyric about that experience. I continued to be highly interested in music, in advancing in my abilities and understanding. I released a CD of 100% my own music, in 2003, and played all the instruments and recorded the whole thing myself. I have more music being worked on for other music and literature projects. Be yourself, understand the difference between a tool and what it helps to make.

It really depends. Obviously if you’re interested in performing it will make you a better performer, but there’s a curse that comes with it too. I was about 12 or 13 when I began to grasp chord theory. I also could figure out the relationship between chords when listening to them (e.g. I- IV). Around that time, instead of simply listening to music my brain would start to analyze it. Since then, that’s the way I listen to music — well, Western music anyway. It’s a blessing because when a student wants to learn a certain song I don’t know, I have it covered; same with being on a gig. The curse is since you’re analyzing all the time, you become picky about what you hear, rather than just enjoying it for what it is.

It largely depends on two factors: 1) How it is taught 2) The predisposition of the person concerned. Now I loved music theory! So much so that as a teen I voluntarily studied it to an advanced level and gained diplomas in it. Mind you, I had an inspiring teacher I looked up to. He at the time was the only blind doctor of music in the UK and had gained his doctorate in bygone years when you had to be able to work papers in 8 part harmony and counterpoint, as well as work an exercise in 8 parts for double choir. Although these skills had long vanished, I asked him to train me in them. I enjoyed the challenge! Of course, to get to that level of study you first need to learn the basics. But I had the motivation because I knew where I wanted to go. And motivation is key. Theory may well seem a joyless experience if you can' t see the point of it. However, even at the most basic level it is music literacy and, at least for a classical musician who learns from the printed page, vital. I would draw an analogy with learning a language: Is it sufficient merely to be able to speak it, or do you need to be able to read it and write it as well? Well, just speaking it will certainly help get you by on your holiday, but if you aspired to proficiency, you would need to take things further. And by the way, it is thanks to the invention of staff notation, developed around 1000 years ago, that classical music has attained such a high level of sophistication. Once composers could conceive their ideas on paper, more complex textures involving counterpoint became possble.

The answer may vary for you based on your mindset and how you think. I was pretty obsessed with all things musical starting in high school. Music theory was fascinating to me because it gave me the means to make predictions about how things would sound ahead of time - it helped me hear things in my head and I could even write music in class and study hall, and it would sound good. I could hear music and know (at least on a basic level at first) what was going on, the note and chords involved… in band class it made sense why the trumpets and the saxophones had different notes… It answered a lot of questions for me. I thought it was the greatest thing ever. So I enjoyed it greatly. Your mileage may vary.

This is a great question and a tricky one… A musician should have some insight about music theory because there is much to learn and it can help connect the dots. Take a C Major scale and learn intervals, chord qualities, convert to melodic minor, harmonic minor, etc. After you’ve done that, close the books and play music you enjoy. When I was in college, I spent hours analyzing classical music. It was great for my musical development. However, I went home, looked at my CD collection, and just froze. Which CD am I supposed to listen to? That unforgettable moment made me realize that too much analysis was interfering with my enjoyment of music. I spoke to a friend about it. Peter is an excellent guitarist who graduated from Peabody. He confessed about music theory burnout as well. His advice was to let go of the analysis, play what you can, listen to what you love, and return to music theory when you’ve hit a wall. It’s a delicate balancing act; you need both. However, too much of anything is not going to yield great results. This is a deeper conversation than music… One final thought is that I have a problem with people who brag about not reading music, but claim they are better musicians because they figured it all out on their own. Really? You mastered music without any help? Books are a bad idea? Pushing your ceiling level is a bad idea? Schooling is a bad idea? Being open minded is a bad idea? In sum, knowledge is still power and being a musician takes one or more lifetimes to truly master. www.evanj31drum.com

“Does learning music theory take the joy out of music?” Not at all. It helps you advance and make better music, thus increasing your joy. Theory, at least in a jazz context, helps me understand why certain things sound the way they do, why they sound like other things, why they sound different, and what sounds good when. And it gives me the tools to know how to brnach out and create new things. It also helps me learn tunes much more quickly by using the language of theory to create a common code for patterns. For example, the bridge to I Got Rhythm in B-flat is D7 - G7 - C7 - F7. Theory tells me that in any given key, the bridge is III7 - VI7 - II7 - V7. Knowing the roman numeral system allows me to see and describe musical structure in any key. If you know theory, you can talk about “two-five” patterns with another musician, and you’d both be on the same page. As for creativity, I was at a concert recently, when Steve Wallace (bass) started soloing on a chorus by starting with (if I recall) an F#7 chord instead of a C7 chord, which the music called for. Now, such a substitution is called a “tritone substitution.” The pianist, Mark Eisenman, was therefore tasked with coming up with the harmony for this new direction that Steve took, and it was quite exciting. Without a knowledge of the tritone substitution, and the harmony around it, they would not have played the section in this very interesting way. At any rate, speaking for jazz at least, your practice sessions need to include these activities: instrument technique (fingerings, tone production, flexibility, whatever)pattern, exercise practice (to become accustomed to common patterns so you can learn new tunes more quickly)learning theoryimprovisation. This is where you play whatever you want, and apply what you’ve learned so far, listen to yourself, write down spontaneous patterns, and give yourself the permission to screw up.So, no, learning theory does not take the joy out of music as long as you apply the theory and give yourself permission to improvise and create music.

No. Not at all. Understanding theory enhances your music experience as a musician. It makes for easy communication with other musicians. If someone tells me “This is a ii V I in G” , I have a real good idea what to do even with out a sheet of music in front of me. It can help you learn songs “by ear” if you have an understanding of chord progressions and keys. Finally, a knowledge of theory is the best way to create your own music. Being able to take a creative melody line and harmonize it with chords or parts for instruments is what it is all about. I think all musicians that play regularly “know” music theory. When they “learn” it, by that I mean, study it at least a little bit, it can only help. Theory is just the language. Knowledge is power, Man. Learn basic theory!

No, learning music theory does not take anything away from your music, if anything, it will add a whole lot of new colours and skills to your musical palette, and it will add a lot of joy to composition, and listening to music. Music theory is really just a bunch of names for tricks, so that we can remember them and use them when writing music, studying other people's music, or trying to figure out songs by ear, etc. In my opinion, it has a lot to do with your teacher, and you; but generally speaking, learning music theory is a really, really good idea!

I believe learning some music theory actually enhances that joy. But IMO learning to read music can severely diminish your ability to interpret music in your own way. Especially for beginners. You’ll become reliant on the sheet music, and won’t be able to play a song unless it’s on the page in front of you. But learning about the circle of fifths, keys, the interaction between keys and chords, is absolutely essential to your growth and development as a musician. But as I said before, I’d learn to do stuff by ear before learning to read music.

Generally, it depends how the information is presented to the student. Because most of the students that I've ever taught have no interest in learning music theory I have had to keep the lessons at a level that the student can enjoy. As the student progresses musically I sneak in little chunks of theory. This without using the ”T" word. Too many people have a negative idea of what music theory really means. Music theory simply is a way of organizing and opening the door to more musical ideas. This in turn allows you to see more possibilities in the chord progressions you choose. It also allows you to view a wider range of possibilities when you improvise.

Learning theory in ADDITION to practice, performance and audition adds to the joy; but if music theory takes so much time and attention that it detracts from playing music with others and for audiences and listening to live music, then YES, it reduces the joy. Music is ephemeral sounds in a room. It is NOT inkspots on paper. Music is not even recordings of music, particularly NOT Internet distribution of music in file compressed downloads and streaming music. The only way to learn to receive and create maximum joy from music is in the room with living masters playing. The most extreme case I have seen is music students and professors reading scores at concerts. They are taking the limited exposure to a composition and performer and diluting it with symbolic visual information. Paper pedagogy and YouTube are why too many conservatory graduates today are mere score slaves, imbuing slightly more expression into scores with slightly more “errors” than MIDI score renderings. An exacerbating factor is the adoption of “pop” recording techniques, with isolation, overdubs, splicing, headphones and artificial reverb in sterile studios instead of playing the entire arc of the composition in a living , breathing room with live audiences. Human is Better Than Perfect.

Oh, yeah. It does. The way learnining English takes the joy out of writing, or studying aerodynamics takes the joy out of flying; mechanical engineering and driving; cooking and cooking; ballet and dancing; art and sketching . . . Need I continue? A musician is one who studies music. That’s it; it’s never-ending. If you want to find the prizes in the middle of the art, you have to know how it’s built, so you can find your way there. That’s what theory is: how music is built. It will show you the way to get real joy out of music. Good Luck and keep playing.

Well, for some people, the answer is yes. For others, learning music theory can be interesting, or even fun. In my opinion, music theory really helps put into perspective how much of an art form music really is. It gets confusing and takes a lot of studying, but for some people, this can actually be therapeutic. When I’m stressed, I will practice writing secondary chords, or analyze a Bach chorale. It’s weird, and I doubt many other people my age do this, but it’s what I like to do. It’s all opinion based.

Not at all. Does learning the alphabet take the joy out of reading? You have to know the basics.How could you play if you don't know what to play? All instruments have theory in common. You can get lost in it for sure. Don't try learning all the complicated stuff. Learn the notes,the terms,how scales are formed.chords too.Its not that hard. Only 7 letters,12 notes.You will become very discouraged quickly without it.

Let me put it this way….theory, depending on how it is taught, can open a new world of understanding, or it can slam the door on creativity and discourage musicianship. I had a very good and innovative college professor who taught theory and I put in three years with her. Ear training was especially challenging. Our textbook was a collection of Bach chorales, and THE CONTRAPUNTAL HARMONIC TECHNIQUE OF THE 18TH CENTURY by Allen Irvine McHose. I also learned (the hard way) that some p;kano or keyboard experience helped a lot. I had my first piano lessons as a college freshman and always regretted that i hadn’t started much younger. Having said that, after i received my degree and got out in the field, I learned more music theory with a baton in my hand in six months than i ever learned in a college classroom. In musical performance, there is a practical application side, and the theoretical side…they are both important.

Oh heck no! Knowing music theory has made me fall even more in love with music. Analyzing chords on a system is like a beautiful puzzle to me, and I do it just for fun sometimes! (Nerd? Yes.) Theory helps us to understand what our music is doing and WHY it sounds the way that it does. It can teach us about the writers and composers, and it can teach about ourselves and the way we think (and our shortcomings, oof). Every musician should learn at least basic theory, if not more than that.

No. It enhances it - once you have learned it anyway. It can take away the fun of playing if the learning process becomes a burden. It’s just like anything else you learn. You can keep going or stop anytime. But the more you learn, the easier the navigation becomes. In my opinion more doors open (artistically) when you are trying to match the emotion with the chords, progression, and/or melody line.

Depends are you a music listener or are you music producer? If you are a producer or composer, learning and understanding music theory definately will make your creation process alot easier. It helps alot. But if you are just a music listener then No. No need to learn theory

Hi. No, of course not. I do know a lot of players who think this is true… …but it's just an excuse for not doing the basic, minimum amount of work needed to convey ideas to knowledgable musicians. And there is no analogy that makes sense for any other profession/hobby. Ex: “Will learning: …auto mechanics take the joy out of driving? …to cook take the joy out of eating food?” (etc.) Cheers!

No, it just makes composing music a bit more difficult, IMHO. There are musicians out there who can write great music without knowing music theory or how to read / write music at all. They can play by ear and memorizing the chords. As with everything in life, there are more than one way to do things.

Me, being a pianist for nine years, i’ve always dreaded having to do music theory. It was so tiresome and tedious. I never really enjoyed learning it. But that was because I never really understood it. And still to this day, I don’t really understand it very well. I’m actually supposed to be a level eight in theory, but i’ve been stuck on the level three book by Keith Snell for three years…oops!… Now, unlike me, some people enjoy music theory, as they get to learn more about the different aspects of piano. So when it comes to that, it’s kind of different for everybody.

No, because doing theory homework is mostly a separate thing from actually playing an instrument or listening to music. You can still enjoy music even if you dislike theory. In fact, if you have enough theory knowledge to play an instrument, it’ll help you enjoy playing it because you wouldn’t be constantly not knowing what note that is or what that rehearsal mark means.

Hell no. Does learning more words take the joy out of writing or speaking? Music theory is like a short cut to understanding music logically. It gives you a vocabulary. It gives you a means to express it on paper (more easily imo) and ability to share it with others. You get ideas from studying others' work, and learn tried and true methods of composing. If you don't like it, you don't have to use it. But at least you have the option.

The more theory I have had, the better I have become as a performer and teacher because my understanding of music is on a deeper level and music has more meaning for me. Practically, understanding theory and musical form makes learning music easier, especially if you are memorizing music. Instead of thinking of a group of notes as a difficult spot, you can see it as part of a scale or chord or sequence, thus making it easier to learn, especially if you have applied your theory to your practicing - in other words you have mastered different scale forms, chords, and chord progressions. Musically, you are better prepared to understand and execute the composers’ intentions. Basic theory should be incorporated into musical training, and much of it is. There is no need to make it dull. Poor teaching of any subject can kill the joy. Higher level theory (college level) is generally taught in classes, but must be applied in music making and listening to be relevant.

I think it can increase it, in the same way learning to read and write can increase the joy of storytelling. Learning requires some focus, but can lead to great freedom. Theory enhances your music ability, therefore leading to an even deeper, wonderful musical experience….IMHO

Oh no! I think it provides a lot of useful insight into the many possible qualities of good music.
